abstract: Bank of America officials will be squaring off on Tuesday night with leaders of several community faith-based organizations that are angry about the bank’s role in the growing number of foreclosures across the country.
snippet: Bank of America officials will be squaring off on Tuesday night with leaders of several community faith-based organizations that are angry about the bank’s role in the growing number of foreclosures across the country.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is facing the power of prayer over foreclosures.

headline.main: A Deal With Bank of America Is in Their Prayers

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.
snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.

headline.main: S.E.C. Sues Bank of America (Again) on Merrill

abstract: The New York Times’s Op-Ed editors asked eight financial experts to pose questions they would like to hear the bankers answer.
snippet: The New York Times’s Op-Ed editors asked eight financial experts to pose questions they would like to hear the bankers answer.
lead_paragraph: Today, the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which Congress established last year to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, is scheduled to question the heads of four big banks — Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America.

headline.main: More Questions for the Finance Chiefs

abstract: John A. Thain, former head of Merrill Lynch who left Bank of America soon after the two companies merged, has reportedly held talks about taking the reins at CIT Group, a commercial lender that recently emerged from bankruptcy.
snippet: John A. Thain, former head of Merrill Lynch who left Bank of America soon after the two companies merged, has reportedly held talks about taking the reins at CIT Group, a commercial lender that recently emerged from bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch who left Bank of America just months after the two companies merged, may be in talks for a new gig.

headline.main: Thain Said to Hold Talks With CIT Over Top Job

abstract: Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008.
snippet: Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Summoned to Capitol Hill to explain their companies’ roles in the worst economic downturn since the Depression, leaders of four big Wall Street banks offered a largely clinical take on the financial crisis on Wednesday, pointing to lapses in risk management and government regulation but offering little sense of the turmoil’s human toll.

headline.main: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take a Meeker Tone on Capitol Hill
headline.print_headline: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take a Meeker Tone on Capitol Hill

abstract: DealBook is live-blogging the hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, where Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America are testifying about the financial crisis.
snippet: DealBook is live-blogging the hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, where Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America are testifying about t...
lead_paragraph: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission heard testimony about the financial crisis from four of the nation’s leading bankers: Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America. (Watch the live video here, via C-Span 2.) DealBook’s Zachery Kouwe live-blogged the hearing, with the most recent entries at the top:

headline.main: Live-Blogging 4 Top Bankers on Capitol Hill

abstract: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.
snippet: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.
lead_paragraph: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.

abstract: A House committee is demanding to see Timothy F. Geithner’s e-mails, phone logs and meeting notes from when he was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in late 2008 and the American International Group was bailed out.
snippet: A House committee is demanding to see Timothy F. Geithner’s e-mails, phone logs and meeting notes from when he was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in late 2008 and the American International Group was bailed out.
lead_paragraph: What was Timothy F. Geithner thinking when the American International Group was bailed out? The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee wants to know.

headline.main: House Panel Demands Geithner’s A.I.G. Records
